invention-noun.title: invention
invention-noun.definition: a new thing or idea that someone has made or thought of.
invention-noun.contextualMeaning: A bright lightbulb appearing above a creative mind, symbolizing a new idea or product coming into existence.
invention-noun.exampleSentence: The internet was a truly groundbreaking invention that changed how people connect.

unspecified-adjective.title: unspecified
unspecified-adjective.contextualMeaning: A blurry calendar or a clock with no hands, suggesting an unknown or vague moment in time.
unspecified-adjective.exampleSentence: The meeting is scheduled for an unspecified time next week.

idiom-noun.title: idiom
idiom-noun.definition: a group of words whose meaning is not clear from the individual words.
idiom-noun.contextualMeaning: A speech bubble containing a confusing image (like raining cats and dogs) that conveys a figurative meaning, not literal.
idiom-noun.exampleSentence: "Break a leg" is an idiom used to wish someone good luck, not for actual injury.

boundaries-noun.title: boundaries
boundaries-noun.definition: the limits or edges of something, often rules or acceptable behavior.
boundaries-noun.contextualMeaning: A clear line on the ground being stepped over, or a fence being pushed through, symbolizing the breaking of limits.
boundaries-noun.exampleSentence: It's important to respect personal boundaries in friendships.

acceptable-adjective.title: acceptable
acceptable-adjective.definition: good enough; allowed or agreed upon.
acceptable-adjective.contextualMeaning: A hand giving a thumbs-up gesture, or a person nodding in approval, indicating something is within limits or agreeable.
acceptable-adjective.exampleSentence: Her grades were acceptable, but she hoped to do better next semester.

fresh-adjective.title: fresh
fresh-adjective.definition: newly made, gathered, or produced; not old or frozen.
fresh-adjective.contextualMeaning: A close-up of vibrant, dewy vegetables just picked, or dough being kneaded with flour, emphasizing newness and natural state.
fresh-adjective.exampleSentence: We bought fresh bread from the bakery this morning.

popular-adjective.title: popular
popular-adjective.definition: liked or enjoyed by many people.
popular-adjective.contextualMeaning: A large crowd cheering, many hands reaching for something, a widely recognized symbol.
popular-adjective.exampleSentence: That new song is very popular right now; everyone is listening to it.

origins-noun.title: origins
origins-noun.definition: the beginning or source of something.
origins-noun.contextualMeaning: A map with a starting point, roots of a tree, an ancient artifact.
origins-noun.exampleSentence: The origins of this ancient custom are still unknown.

recipes-noun.title: recipes
recipes-noun.definition: sets of instructions for making food.
recipes-noun.contextualMeaning: An open cookbook with ingredients laid out, someone following cooking instructions.
recipes-noun.exampleSentence: My grandmother has many old recipes for delicious cakes.

spread-verb.title: spread
spread-verb.definition: to move or make something move over a wide area.
spread-verb.contextualMeaning: A hand scattering seeds, ripples in water, a map with expanding arrows.
spread-verb.exampleSentence: The news of the discovery quickly spread around the world.

migration-noun.title: migration
migration-noun.definition: the movement of people or animals from one place to another.
migration-noun.contextualMeaning: A flock of birds flying in a V-formation across the sky, or people with backpacks crossing a border, showing seasonal or necessary relocation.
migration-noun.exampleSentence: Bird migration happens every year as they search for warmer climates.

settlement-noun.title: settlement
settlement-noun.definition: a place where people establish a community.
settlement-noun.contextualMeaning: A group of small houses or tents in a remote area, people building homes from scratch, emphasizing the idea of forming a new community.
settlement-noun.exampleSentence: The first settlement in the area was established over 300 years ago.

practical-adjective.title: practical
practical-adjective.definition: useful and effective in real situations.
practical-adjective.contextualMeaning: A person fixing something with simple tools, or using clever everyday solutions—emphasizing real-life usefulness.
practical-adjective.exampleSentence: Wearing waterproof boots is a practical choice on a rainy day.

specific-adjective.title: specific
specific-adjective.contextualMeaning: A red circle around a word in a document, or someone pointing to one object among many—illustrating exactness.
specific-adjective.exampleSentence: He asked for a specific brand of coffee, not just any kind.

concepts-noun.title: concepts
concepts-noun.definition: ideas or principles that help understand or explain something.
concepts-noun.contextualMeaning: Light bulbs floating above heads, puzzle pieces fitting together—symbolizing understanding or mental models.
concepts-noun.exampleSentence: The teacher explained the basic concepts of physics.

porridge-noun.title: porridge
porridge-noun.definition: a hot food made by boiling oats or other grains in milk or water.
porridge-noun.contextualMeaning: A warm bowl of oats with steam rising and a spoon inside—conveying comfort and traditional breakfast food.
porridge-noun.exampleSentence: She eats porridge with honey and bananas every morning.

spoon-noun.title: spoon
spoon-noun.definition: a tool with a shallow bowl and a handle, used for eating or serving food.
spoon-noun.contextualMeaning: A metal spoon scooping soup from a bowl or children eating with colorful spoons—showing utility and common daily use.
spoon-noun.exampleSentence: He stirred his tea with a small silver spoon.

sweetener-noun.title: sweetener
sweetener-noun.definition: a substance used to make food or drink taste sweet.
sweetener-noun.contextualMeaning: A spoonful of sugar or packets labeled ‘zero-calorie’ being poured into tea—conveying the idea of adding sweetness.
sweetener-noun.exampleSentence: She prefers natural honey as a sweetener in her tea.

symbolize-verb.title: symbolize
symbolize-verb.definition: to represent something else through a sign or symbol.
symbolize-verb.contextualMeaning: A dove representing peace or a heart symbol standing for love—indicating abstract ideas through objects or signs.
symbolize-verb.exampleSentence: The white flag symbolizes surrender in many cultures.

mutually-adverb.title: mutually
mutually-adverb.definition: in a way that is shared by two or more parties.
mutually-adverb.contextualMeaning: Two people shaking hands, or arrows pointing both ways—illustrating shared agreement or impact.
mutually-adverb.exampleSentence: They reached a mutually beneficial agreement.
